newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: ASEAN fundamentals still strong - Singapore minister.
newsitem.headline: ASEAN fundamentals still strong - Singapore minister.

text.p: Southeast Asian economic fundamentals remain strong despite recent setbacks to exports in the region, Singapore Trade Minister Yeo Cheow Tong said on Wednesday.

"With our strong fundamentals, ASEAN (Association of Southeast Asian Nations) will remain one of the fastest growing regions in the world," Yeo said in a speech to the Thailand-Singapore Business Council.

He noted media reports suggesting a "slightly less than positive outlook" for ASEAN economies. "In particular, export growth in several ASEAN countries has slowed considerably compared to the year before."
Thailand's export growth was only six percent in first-half 1996 and Singapore recorded a six percent export decline in June, Yeo said.
But while such slowdowns are likely to have some impact on economic growth, he said fundamentally growth momentum remained strong and sustainable.

"Much of the current problem in export growth is cyclical," Yeo said. The global slowdown in electronics, which is dragging down exports, comes after several years of hectic growth, and a breather could be expected," he said.
Yeo said a second reason for optimism was the wave of liberalisation and deregulation sweeping Asia with spectacular economic results, Yeo said,
"The transformation of China in particular has been astonishing. As it opens up, China will suck in imports from all over the world, including ASEAN."
ASEAN groups Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore, Brunei, Indonesia, the Philippines, and Vietnam.
